data.title: Fix crash on TextEdit complex operations redo.
data.body: A null pointer crash would occur before if you tried to redo past a complex operation in the text editor. This should resolve it.

data.title: BoneAttachments now position themselves instantly during bind.
data.body: Simply makes it so that a BoneAttachment node will reposition itself to the bone it's attaching itself to instantly on a rebind. Makes working with this node in the editor a little bit easier to determine what's going to attach itself to where.

data.title: Fixed curve baking, now always start at origin point
data.body:
Fix for https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/4318
Basically add always origin point to bake list on curve 2d

data.title: Make the code that colors functions and member variables smarter
data.body:
As the title says.
## The issue right now

The code for coloring the text for functions and member variables is fairly simplistic at the moment, the function coloring colors every piece of text before a pair of parenthesis and the member variable coloring colors every piece of text after a period.
## What can be done about it?

How about making the system smarter by using information gleaned from parsing the code in the editor.
- Only color member variables that are known to exist. Otherwise leave the text white.
- Only color functions that are known to exist (and only if the inheritance is correct). Otherwise leave the text white.
- For both, you could even have the editor throw an error if it's a safe bet that said white text would stop the game (I know we may not be able to catch everything, that's why I said a 'safe' bet).

---

In a sense, use the color feature to help developers write working code more of the time so there's less time quashing errors.

Comments?

data.title: Tilemap collisions not updated during _fixed_process
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.0.2, Windows 7 64 bits:

I have a tilemap where tiles have collision shapes. I use them to perform raycasts and intersections.

To develop a new feature, I need to modify the tilemap during the _fixed_process() callback.
But when I cast rays to new tiles, they pass through as if there were no tiles Oo

Then I realized the tiles become "collisionnable" ONE frame AFTER.
This is a big problem in my game, because working around that means I have to introduce a special case for every collision query I make... and this is going to produce a lot of potential bugs with all the logic I already have working.

Is this known to be a design constraint, or is it a bug?

data.title: TileSet: It does not support all features Sprite (Bug)
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
all

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Property "Vframes", "Hframes", "Frame" not supported in the TileSet.
Instead, they must use the "region". But it is not always convenient.

It is desirable that the tiles can be created from any 2D objects. Let the solution of the tile that will be left for the developers. It would be more correct.

data.title: animation_started signal for AnimationPlayer
data.body: signal is called `animation_started` and have one parameter `name` of the animation that had just started

data.title: On Path2d follower doesn't start at origin position
data.body:
Hello,
I'm trying to coordinate two or more paths for my camera movement on my shmup, when one path is finished, another start at the same position, this is for different camera speeds, but I noticed a noticeable skip on scroll when the camera change to another path.
Now working on an animation I found the reason, **It's seems that the baking intervals put the first point after the first interval**, for example if you has a straight line as path:
![Image of line](http://i.imgur.com/7vkUZN8.png)
On blue is the path drawing on godot
On orange is the baked path generated by godot with an interval of 5, notice how the orange line start at 5, same has baked interval value.
The follower of the path, follows the baked orange line and skip 0-5 portion from origin because for some reason the baking algorithm doesn't start by add a bake point on the origin

Here is an image of a missile sprite which doesn't start at origin with unit offset on 0 using a baked interval of 5, look at the position too, is 5 on Y axis and should be 0, so is happening what I described on top
![Image of check_this_five](http://i.imgur.com/HuswEyt.png)

**How to reproduce?**
1. Create a Path 2d and his curve
2. Create a visible follower for the path
3. Set the baked interval of the curve to 5 or more for example.
4. Set the Unit Offset of the follower to 0 and look how doesn't start at origin position of the path

Here is a project ready for debug this error:
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/s/f00jmkmkxcyir0d/path_2d_bug.zip?dl=0

data.title: correct typo "overwrite"
data.body: correct typo "Owerwrite" to "Overwrite" in **Import 3D Scene** popup window.

data.title: Different visual shader outputs between two GPUS
data.body:
**Updated with new info**
**Operating system or device:**
PC1 (notebook)
http://i.imgur.com/gMPJ4gu.png
PC2 (Desktop)
http://i.imgur.com/ZUI6s9S.png
PC3
Intel® Core™ i5-3320M CPU
64Bit Zorin OS 10 (Linux)
4gb DDR3 Ram
Intel-4000 Graphics 

Godot >= 2.0.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I developed a method for old school color swap with shaders using color palettes and a grey mask, which should be fast and has a low memory overhead.

Shader accept two textures:
A Greyscale texture which is the Grey Mask
A Palette texture where each pixel is a color of the palette (Nx1 size)
Grey Mask has correlative colors where his RGB value represent the index of a pixel color on the palette.
An image which explain better the theory:
![Image of explanation](http://i.imgur.com/IDz2Lp9.png)

So on computers with **AMD Graphics** the result is as **EXPECTED**:
https://gfycat.com/ImmensePoshElectriceel
And on computers with **Intel Graphics** the result is **WRONG**:
https://gfycat.com/ImmediateInformalEmu
Nvidia untested

Note: a visually reference of which palette gets applied to megaman on each button press is on right side, on the intel video for some reason the shader uses the wrong color for the second color of palette.

The shader code:

```
uniform texture palette;
uniform float palette_size;
uniform texture mask;
vec4 mask_color = tex(mask,UV);
vec4 output = tex(TEXTURE,UV);
if(mask_color.r != 1.0)
{
    output = tex(palette,vec2((mask_color.r*255.0)/(palette_size),0.0));
}
COLOR.rgba = output;

```

The culprit is the `palette_size` var, this is an uniform float which represents the width of the palette texture, is updated at gdscript with an int value when is required:
output = tex(palette,vec2((mask_color.r*255.0)/`palette_size`,0.0));

The `palette_size` is different between Intel vs Amd/Nvidia for some reason, could be something about float precision on the GPU or int to float casting. I managed to find a work around about this issue, but is a patch, a bad one I think because a formula written on paper, should behave the same on code always. The work around is to subtract 0.001 to `palette_size`:
output = tex(palette,vec2((mask_color.r*255.0)/(`palette_size-0.001`),0.0));
This behaves the same on all desktop GPUS.

Much more detailed info about the implementation and algorithm used here:
http://www.godotengine.org/qa/2935/best-colour-palettes-asking-again-cause-last-time-didnt-help?show=2979#a2979

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Download the project with the implementation on a computer with an Intel Graphics GPU (Updated with my last finds):
  https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/s/4axz8j3k359m5a1/pallete_swap_bug.zip?dl=0
- Open it with godot >= 2.0.1 using the intel graphics, if you have a notebook with a dedicated+integrated graphic card, on amd control panel set the godot editor to Power Saving mode. Here a illustrative video how to do that:
  https://gfycat.com/NauticalVillainousAustraliankestrel
  For Nvidia I don't know, I don't have a computer with Nvidia at hand.
  Also don't tested on mobile devices.
- Press the buttons to change megaman from different palettes, look if megaman uses the 0,1,2 color of each palette (visual references from palettes on the right side of buttons)

Shader is on megaman sprite, the script on megaman is for texture and hud management

data.title: can't remove space key from ui_accept
data.body:
I am trying to remove the space key from ui_accept, but it wont work. It seems like the removal of keys from the default mappings is not properly saving. If I remove space from ui_accept and then save->close->reopen project it shows back up in the mapping every time.

I am running Elementary OS(Ubuntu) and a up-to-date copy of the master branch.

data.title: AnimationTreePlayer filters need to be more usable
data.body:
Together with AnimationTree player there are ainmation filters which allow us to
fight importer stupidity a bit and have more control over animation blends.

These filters are really something not known to general public and are not that easy to grasp and use.
The obvious use case is - you imported breathe animation, and you want to add it to walk, idle,
and sit down animation. But as importer imports all bones, the animation will blend not only changed bones, but also unchanged ones, which lead to invalid/strange blends, like half-sitting man, etc.
Filter allows choice which animation tracks to include in blend.

I think this should be re-shufled. We need separate filter node, which gets animation in (after whatever
nodes on its path) and gives out animation with tracks removed.
All other blend support can be removed from UI then. Also we need nice clean UI to edit animations filters with many tracks. Otherwise, these could be exported/imported to/from text format like json or plain lines of text. Ideas?

@JoshuaGrams I think you might share your ideas about this.

data.title: Performance increase on Windows
data.body:
I just ran quick tests in GDScript to see how fast it performs, things like that:

```
    _time_before = OS.get_ticks_msec()

    start()

    for i in range(0,ITERATIONS):
        # Simple code

    _for_time = stop()
    print("For time: " + str(_for_time))
```

And I quickly realized that the version of Godot I built is 5 times faster than the official 2.0.2.
I didn't modified anything in SCons or Godot, just ran a build after following this tutorial from GamesFromScratch: http://www.gamefromscratch.com/post/2015/06/18/Godot-and-Visual-Studio.aspx

As discussed on IRC, this could be caused by the use of another compiler.
So I tried with prior versions, and 2.0.0 is also 5 times faster than 2.0.1 and 2.0.2.
I personally used msvc12, but msvc14 could be even better.

If we can get such performance gains, would it be possible to provide builds made with these compilers on the appropriate platforms?

data.title: Feature- dragonbones json animation data importer
data.body:
This came out as a hot topic on the godot facebook group.

Right now the open source community is looking for an open standard json file format that stores animation data in the form of keyframes.

We have an addon for blender that does that already:
https://github.com/ndee85/coa_tools
It is compatible with Godot too!

**What are the technical advantages of having game animation stored as a json file+ an image atlas?**
- Your game uses much less memory - as only one frame is used and the animation (movement of body parts) is being driven by the game engine's runtime. You get better framerate!
- Your animation can be procedurally altered during runtime - since the runtime is driving it, the programmer can layer ontop or override animations. For example you can have your player character's head turn in the direction of a specific object on the screen.
- Your game/app uses much less HD space - smaller file size makes it much better for mobile development where file size is important.
- You can swap body parts of your character, as the animation is running. This makes it very easy to implement an equipment system that actually affects the way your character looks or reuse the same animations an all the enemies you want in the game - while having them look different.

**What other software can use this technique and export animation data to a json file?**
- Spine 2d
- Spriter
- Creature
- anime studio
- toonboom harmony

**Popular games that use it:**
- rayman origins, rayman legends,  dragon's crown, etc etc

**What open source software can do this already?**
- Godot and Blender (via coa tools)

**The problem with the json file format, the game runtime and the lack of one open standard:**
The three major competing applications for cut out game animation do basically the same things. However as a means to lock their users to their product, the structure of the json files they output is different. That forces game developers to have to rewrite a new run time for each of the three - that parses the data accordingly. What is worse - they put a license on their runtimes that prohibits anyone else  - who does not own the license to their software to use their runtimes.

**To sum it up:**
We need a json file specification that is open - one that can work on all game engines without the need to purchase a license from someone.

Somehow this json specification must be kept compatible in all open source editors or runtimes - so as to not have to duplicate effort to implement new runtimes for each game engine.

Perhaps we need to create a new github/web page for it? One that describes the structure of the specification - and makes it easy for other developers to implement exporters/importers/runtimes.

If we coordinate this between all open source projects that have interest in exporting json animation data - all can benefit from one runtime! In return that runtime will also benefit from them as well - becoming more widely used and supported than it's proprietary counterparts.

data.title: Unify get_pos() / get_translation()
data.body:
I gave a try to 3D in Godot and I got confused by the naming convention.
In 2D, you use get_pos() and get_rot(), but in 3D it's get_translation() and get_rotation().
This got me to write errors in my code everytime because of the different names.
I think the names of these functions should be unified for clarity, because they do the same thing in space.

data.title: Making a very thin ProgressBar
data.body:
It is currently not possible to make a very thin ProgressBar (in height, not width).

I'd like to have such progress bars for health bars above enemies, but I can't make them less high, even if they don't contain any text and use flat styling.

data.title: Shorthand for get_node()
data.body: `get_node()` is a very frequently used function. An alias like `$()` or `@()` could help increase productivity, as something that's built into Godot (just like `$()` is built into jQuery).

data.title: AnimationTreePlayer: fix discrete value tracks.
data.body:
Discrete value tracks don't update every frame (only when a new key is
reached).  So we can't use the actual property value as an accumulator:
it will end up being zero most of the time.

And adding to my collection of test projects: this one tests this commit and the previous one on this branch.

[particle-animations.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/217044/particle-animations.zip)

data.title: Input.is_action_pressed("a") does not behave the same as event.is_action_pressed("a") on doubleclick
data.body:
on v2.0.1_stable

If you try both of these statements in an _input(event) function, event.is_action_pressed("a") will return true and Input.is_action_pressed("a") will return false if the action "a" was triggered by a doubleclick.

example code:

```
func _ready():
    set_process_input(true)

func _input(event):
    if event.type == 3 and event.is_pressed():
        print(event.is_action_pressed("a"), Input.is_action_pressed("a"))
```

after creating action "a" and setting its input to a mouse click, upon testing it should print "true true for the first click then "true false" for the second click of the doubleclick.

data.title: Add a function to find out if an instance has been freed
data.body:
Please add a global function that lets us check if an instance has already been freed.

I know, it's possible to avoid this situation by meticulously enforcing the order in which objects are removed from scene and object references are freed, but sometimes it would take tremendous effort to refactor the code to free the instance correctly / only once.

Currently, if an object was part of a display tree and its parent / grandparent has been freed, the object would be freed along with the parent, and a variable pointing to it would become invalid.

Attempting to call any function on this instance results in:
`Attempt to call function 'FUNCTION_NAME' in base 'previously freed instance' on a null instance.`

Since the Godot runtime is able to detect this and break with an error, I assume there's a way to check if an instance pointed at by a variable has been freed or not.

It would be a very very helpful addition and could save many hours of debugging. Something like:

`bool is_instance_valid( variable )`

Thankee sai.

data.title: Timer Feature Request
data.body: For more flexibility with timers in loops, you should make the timer.start() work once(not talking about oneshot) so the timer does not reset when timer.start() is called over and over, but allow a second function or a condition to be called that allows for this. Ex: timer.reset_and_start(), or timer.start(Bool reset)

data.title: Simple mesh editing tools
data.body:
I miss some simple mesh editing capability in Godot.

By "simple"  mean a way to move a bunch of verticies around to do a quick fix of a without the need to reimport.

data.title: Broken class image
data.body:
Broken class image
Image generated texture is completely black, here's an example of my script ...

```
extends Quad
export (int) var Xpix = 128
export (int) var Ypix = 128

func _ready():
    _update_texture()
    pass


func _update_texture():

    var IMEGE = Image( Xpix, Ypix, false, 4)
    print(str(IMEGE.get_height())+"_size_"+str(IMEGE.get_width()))

    for i in range(Xpix):
        for j in range(Ypix):
            IMEGE.put_pixel( i, j, Color(i*j*64*128),0)
    IMEGE.save_png("res://SAVED_DATA/test_PNG_pix.png")


    var IMEGE_TEXTURE = ImageTexture.new()

    IMEGE_TEXTURE.set_data(IMEGE)
#   IMEGE_TEXTURE.create_from_image(IMEGE,7 )


    var MAT = FixedMaterial.new()
    MAT.set_name("MAT")

    MAT.set_texture(0,IMEGE_TEXTURE)

#   MAT.set_fixed_flag(0,true)#FLAG_USE_ALPHA = 0

    set_material_override(MAT)
```

data.title: Information required on generating Navigation/NavigationMesh from code
Exposed Control::focus_mode to the scene editor
data.body:
Allows fine-tuning of tab focusing without using scripts.

Exposed `get_focus_mode()` to the script
Added `focus_mode` to the property panels for line-edit and sliders
Added `enabled_focus_mode` to the property panels for buttons

enabled_focus_mode is used when button is enabled/disabled

data.title: Keep editable instances data when replacing tree root node
data.body:
Fixes #4297

Ping @reduz since I am not sure if we want to expose `data.editable_instances` to outsiders :)

data.title: SurfaceTool needs add_quad method
data.body:
It is simple enough to implement, but I have no time so
To improve speed of generation algorithms (and reduce script sizes), the quad
method should be added to SurfaceTool.
GDScript implementation:

``` gdscript
class mysf extends SurfaceTool:
    func add_tri(uvs, pts):
            if uvs.size() != pts.size():
                    return
            for k in range(uvs.size()):
                    add_uv(uvs[k])
                    add_vertex(pts[k])
    func add_quad(pts, uvs):
            var pts1 = [pts[0], pts[1], pts[3]]
            var pts2 = [pts[1], pts[2], pts[3]]
            var uvs1 = [uvs[0], uvs[1], uvs[3]]
            var uvs2 = [uvs[1], uvs[2], uvs[3]]
            add_tri(uvs1, pts1)
            add_tri(uvs2, pts2)
```
